natural problem: John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives?
natural solution: We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));

label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.

If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area $20\cdot 20/2=200$ square units and a parallelogram of area $20\cdot 40=800$ square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>t. if t \<ge> 0 \<and> t \<le> 1/3 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "integral\<^sup>L (\<lambda>t. P t) 0 1 = 1"
shows  "probability P 0 (5/18) = 5/18"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));
 label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area $20\cdot 20/2=200$ square units and a parallelogram of area $20\cdot 40=800$ square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>t. if t \<ge> 0 \<and> t \<le> 1/3 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "integral\<^sup>L (\<lambda>t. P t) 0 1 = 1"
shows  "probability P 0 (5/18) = 5/18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a probability distribution function $P(t) = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if} \; 0 \leq t \leq \frac{1}{3}, \\ 0 & \text{otherwise}, \end{cases}$ find the probability of an event occurring in the interval $[0, \frac{5}{18}]$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<integral>\<^sup>+ x. indicator {2..3} x * (\<integral>\<^sup>+ y. indicator {x..x + 20} y \<partial>lborel) \<partial>lborel) / (\<integral>\<^sup>+ x. indicator {2..3} x * (\<integral>\<^sup>+ y. indicator {2..3} y \<partial>lborel) \<partial>lborel)"
shows  "P = 5 / 18"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));
 label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area $20\cdot 20/2=200$ square units and a parallelogram of area $20\cdot 40=800$ square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<integral>\<^sup>+ x. indicator {2..3} x * (\<integral>\<^sup>+ y. indicator {x..x + 20} y \<partial>lborel) \<partial>lborel) / (\<integral>\<^sup>+ x. indicator {2..3} x * (\<integral>\<^sup>+ y. indicator {2..3} y \<partial>lborel) \<partial>lborel)"
shows  "P = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the probability P of a point (x, y) lying in the region defined by $2 \le x \le 3$ and $x \le y \le x + 20$, given that the total area of interest is the square with vertices at (2, 2), (2, 3), (3, 2), and (3, 3). The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>t. 2 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> P t = 1/3"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. t < 2 \<or> t > 3 \<longrightarrow> P t = 0"
and h2 : "integral {2..3} (\<lambda>t. (5/9) * P t) = probability"
shows  "probability = 5 / 18"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));
 label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area $20\cdot 20/2=200$ square units and a parallelogram of area $20\cdot 40=800$ square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>t. 2 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> P t = 1/3"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. t < 2 \<or> t > 3 \<longrightarrow> P t = 0"
and h2 : "integral {2..3} (\<lambda>t. (5/9) * P t) = probability"
shows  "probability = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A continuous probability function $P(t)$ is defined such that $P(t) = \frac{1}{3}$ when $2 \leq t \leq 3$, and $P(t) = 0$ when $t < 2$ or $t > 3$. Find the probability corresponding to the integral of $\frac{5}{9} \cdot P(t)$ from $t = 2$ to $t = 3$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes train_arrival john_arrival :: real
assumes h0 : "uniform 0 1 train_arrival"
and h1 : "uniform 0 1 john_arrival"
shows  "P(train_arrival \<le> john_arrival \<and> john_arrival \<le> train_arrival + 20/60) = 5/18"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}

 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes train_arrival john_arrival :: real
assumes h0 : "uniform 0 1 train_arrival"
and h1 : "uniform 0 1 john_arrival"
shows  "P(train_arrival \<le> john_arrival \<and> john_arrival \<le> train_arrival + 20/60) = 5/18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A train arrives at a station uniformly at a random time between 0 and 1 hour. John also arrives at the station uniformly at a random time between 0 and 1 hour. What is the probability that John arrives at the station within 20 minutes of the train's arrival? The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_train_wait :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and P_john_arrive :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "uniform_pdf P_train_wait 2 3"
and h1 : "uniform_pdf P_john_arrive 2 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>t. 2 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> P_train_wait t \<ge> P_john_arrive (t - 20 / 60)"
shows  "probability P_john_arrive (\<lambda>t. P_train_wait t \<ge> P_john_arrive (t - 20 / 60)) = 5 / 18"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));
 label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.

 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P_train_wait :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and P_john_arrive :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "uniform_pdf P_train_wait 2 3"
and h1 : "uniform_pdf P_john_arrive 2 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>t. 2 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> P_train_wait t \<ge> P_john_arrive (t - 20 / 60)"
shows  "probability P_john_arrive (\<lambda>t. P_train_wait t \<ge> P_john_arrive (t - 20 / 60)) = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A train arrives at a station uniformly between 2:00 PM and 3:00 PM. John arrives at the station uniformly between 2:00 PM and 3:00 PM. If the train arrives at the same time or after John, what is the probability that John will catch the train, considering that he needs at least 20 minutes to board the train? The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes train_arrival :: real
and john_arrival :: real
and p :: real
assumes h0 : "train_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h1 : "john_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h2 : "20/60 = p * (1 - abs (train_arrival - john_arrival))"
shows  "p = 5 / 18"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));
 label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area $20\cdot 20/2=200$ square units and a parallelogram of area $20\cdot 40=800$ square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes train_arrival :: real
and john_arrival :: real
and p :: real
assumes h0 : "train_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h1 : "john_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h2 : "20/60 = p * (1 - abs (train_arrival - john_arrival))"
shows  "p = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A train arrives at the station between 2 and 3 hours after midnight. John also arrives at the station between 2 and 3 hours after midnight. The probability that John and the train arrive within 20 minutes of each other is given by $p * (1 - |train\_arrival - john\_arrival|)$. Find the value of $p$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes train_arrival john_arrival :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "train_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h1 : "john_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h2 : "train_arrival + 20 / 60 \<ge> john_arrival"
shows  "P(john_arrival) = 5 / 18"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}

 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));

 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes train_arrival john_arrival :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "train_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h1 : "john_arrival \<in> {2..3}"
and h2 : "train_arrival + 20 / 60 \<ge> john_arrival"
shows  "P(john_arrival) = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: John and a train arrive at the train station between 2 and 3 o'clock. The train arrives 20 minutes before John. What is the probability that John arrives at the train station at a specific time between 2 and 3 o'clock? The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability x \<and> probability x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3) = 1"
and h2 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 - 20 / 60) = 5 / 18"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. (\<exists>t. 2 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 3 \<and> x \<ge> t \<and> x \<le> t + 20 / 60)) = 5 / 18"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));
 label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area $20\cdot 20/2=200$ square units and a parallelogram of area $20\cdot 40=800$ square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability x \<and> probability x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3) = 1"
and h2 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3 - 20 / 60) = 5 / 18"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. (\<exists>t. 2 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 3 \<and> x \<ge> t \<and> x \<le> t + 20 / 60)) = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Suppose that the probability of an event occurring in the interval $[2, 3]$ is $1$. If the probability of the event occurring in the interval $[2, 2 + \frac{20}{60}]$ is $\frac{5}{18}$, find the probability that there exists a time $t$ in the interval $[2, 3]$ such that the event occurs in the interval $[t, t + \frac{20}{60}]$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes train_arrival_time john_arrival_time :: real
assumes h0 : "train_arrival_time \<in> {2..3}"
and h1 : "john_arrival_time \<in> {2..3}"
and h2 : "train_arrival_time + 20/60 = train_departure_time"
shows  "P {train_arrival_time \<le> john_arrival_time \<and> john_arrival_time \<le> train_departure_time} = 5 / 18"

 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes train_arrival_time john_arrival_time :: real
assumes h0 : "train_arrival_time \<in> {2..3}"
and h1 : "john_arrival_time \<in> {2..3}"
and h2 : "train_arrival_time + 20/60 = train_departure_time"
shows  "P {train_arrival_time \<le> john_arrival_time \<and> john_arrival_time \<le> train_departure_time} = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A train arrives at a station between 2:00 and 3:00 PM. The train stays at the station for 20 minutes before departing. John also arrives at the station between 2:00 and 3:00 PM. What is the probability that John arrives at the station while the train is still there? The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes train_arrival :: real and john_arrival :: real and P :: real
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> train_arrival"
and h1 : "train_arrival \<le> 3"
and h2 : "2 \<le> john_arrival"
and h3 : "john_arrival \<le> 3"
and h4 : "train_arrival \<le> john_arrival"
and h5 : "john_arrival \<le> train_arrival + 1/3"
shows  "P = 5 / 18"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 John needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 2:00 and 3:00, waits for 20 minutes, and then leaves. If John also arrives randomly between 2:00 and 3:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when John arrives? The final Answer is \frac{5}{18}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  John arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where John arrives while the train is there. [asy] draw((0,0)--(60,0)); draw((0,0)--(0,60)--(60,60)--(60,0));
 label("2:00", (0,0), SW); label("3:00", (60,0), S); label("3:00", (0,60), W); label("2:20",(20,0),S); fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,40)--(20,0)--cycle, gray(.7)); [/asy] The probability that John arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area $20\cdot 20/2=200$ square units and a parallelogram of area $20\cdot 40=800$ square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $1000/3600=\boxed{\frac{5}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes train_arrival :: real and john_arrival :: real and P :: real
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> train_arrival"
and h1 : "train_arrival \<le> 3"
and h2 : "2 \<le> john_arrival"
and h3 : "john_arrival \<le> 3"
and h4 : "train_arrival \<le> john_arrival"
and h5 : "john_arrival \<le> train_arrival + 1/3"
shows  "P = 5 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A train arrives at the station between 2 and 3 hours after a certain time, and John arrives at the station between 2 and 3 hours after the same time. John arrives no earlier than the train and no later than 1/3 of an hour after the train. What is the probability that both the train and John arrive at the station during the same 1/3-hour period? The final answer is $\frac{5}{18}$.
